pros: The clinical operators/leaders at Dell Children's are AMAZING and the best in town!  There  is a true sense of teamwork and family.  I love coming to work and serving the mission and my team.
cons: Dell Children's is part of Seton which is part of Ascension Health.  With the current economic and political challenges in healthcare, America's greatest healthcare providers are struggling to survive in a world where insurance companies are covering less (with higher deductibles/out of pocket for families) and pharmaceutical companies are exorbitantly raising prices (on life-saving treatments). Unfortunately, this is adversely impacting the pediatric world, one of the most vulnerable populations in America.  We are constantly being treated and forced to operate like an adult facility within Ascension with very little autonomy to operate like a true pediatric trauma hospital.  This is inevitably causing burnout of the most talented and passionate associates, who are being forced to do more with less resources.  The pay is NOT competitive when living in Austin.

review_title: Once upon a time, this was a great place to work....
pros: Used to be great, when it was Brackenridge and Seton , and there were plenty of employees.
cons: Changed for the worst, when Ascension fully took over. Please be aware, it is ASCENSION, just operating under the Seton name. Seton, for all intents and purposes, is gone.  Once upon a time, Seton was a great company to work for. Those days are gone. There are NEVER enough staff now to keep up with work flow. Employees are run like slaves now, and turnover is outrageous. The management in the imaging department at UMCB all turned upon one another and their staff as things became worse, in order to attempt to save themselves. It really didn't work for them, as Ascension had their own agenda from the beginning. Now, Ascension attempts to run a level 1 trauma center like a walk in clinic. Stay away from this facility (DSMCUT) at all costs. I never worked at any of the other Seton hospitals, but heard they were just as bad.  Really, much of healthcare has become abysmal, trying to run as thin as possible, attempting to send people home early, which is simply theft from employees to enrich upper managers and parasites.

review_title: I stay here because I care about the patients and their families.
pros:
You make many connections when troubleshooting department issues (IT staff, other managers and assistants)
I have my own laptop to work off of and can take it home if I need to should I be ill.
Multidisciplinary teams are VERY inspiring.
The people who are part of my team are amazing! What we stand for and the difference we make together keeps me here.
Also, the healthcare benefits are nice.
cons:
What is a bonus?
Processes are very slow as far as getting things done (posting jobs, hiring, finding space for a growing clinic, etc.).
Some politics between providers.
Salary is determined by finding the median pay for your position in the area around you (meaning, they won't compare you to a salary in NY, or something). Even if you deserve more, a real raise feels unlikely. Or if they agree to it, it takes forever to get it reviewed/approved/enforced.
Losing talent because of pay, slow processes, etc.

review_title: All about the money. Time to jump ship.
pros: The bedside staff that work in the trenches despite the low pay & no respect from Higher-ups
cons:
Where do I begin???

Upper management has no respect for their nurses. I recently attended a town hall where CEO Tad Hatton spoke to the staff like we were children and dismissed our concerns. It was insulting. The entire Town Hall was just a patronizing tactic. The higher ups are overpaid while the bedside staff providing patient care are incredibly underpaid-especially considering the high cost of living in Austin. The medical-surgical floors at Seton Main are terribly outdated. Layoffs galore, which means more work falls to nurses. As a night charge nurse, I spend many hours making sandwiches in the kitchen, stripping dirty rooms & restocking supplies! So obviously, I'm not practicing to the highest level of my license. We have come so far from our focus-patient care. Every meeting is about budget, reimbursement, HCAPS, and other administrative concerns. I cannot recall the last time I attended a meeting and spoke about anything MEDICAL. That is all secondary.

pros: I honestly have no pros other than I enjoyed most of the peers I worked with.
cons: Middle and upper management are extremely disconnected with staff.  My management had no idea what nurses in their departments did, therefore they were inept at properly managing.  Their only concern is doing what their senior management tells them to do regardless of safe practice.  When an absurd request is made of you there is no one to support or protect you. You are expected to do what you're told regardless of your experience or training.  In fact,  Seton has recently added a little blurb on their job responsibilities that states "performs other duties as assigned" with no regard to what areas or departments you have experience or training in.  Everyone is worried about keeping their job, so no one will speak up, nor support you.  If you decide to work for Seton (especially Seton Northwest do so at your own risk).  Their mission is complete hog wash!  They stand by nothing their mission states.

pros: Most the workers are nice people. They provide decent benefits. Good mission for treating patients with humancare.
cons: The facilities are dirty because of budget cuts, making for general areas and offices to not be cleaned often, if ever. There are cockroaches in the facility - a hospital. Associates have to walk a long distance to parking - which associates pay for.  Office equipment is old and not adequate. There is only 1 option for meals, the cafeteria. Communication and transparency is very poor. Even when leadership changes, official communication takes weeks to go out to staff announcing the change, which by then is a moot point because the rumor-mill has already learned the news. This creates for a very dis-trusting environment. It is clear that local hospital leadership doesn't align with the network leadership decisions. There is a "us" vs. "them" mentality. There is a poor system for addressing patient concerns.

review_title: Due to budget cuts, staffing is kept to a minimum in vital departments, putting patient safety at risk.
job_title: Registered Pharmacy Technician in Austin, TX
pros: Seton does provide excellent benefits at a very low minimum hours per week requirement, including insurance (medical, dental, vision), and the coverage is reasonably good. They also have a tuition reimbursement program which is activated after a year of working there, up to $2000 a year, regardless of the type of class. You are also guaranteed whatever number of hours you were hired to work.
cons: When faced with budget constraints, employers will force you to use the paid time off you have a accrued and take days off that you did not request. You must turn in time off requests over a month in advance. Very poor communication between shifts, poor conflict management and resolution, low morale, extreme cases of favoritism, impossible to climb employee promotion ladder.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Maybe a pro to some, might be a con. Depending on which section if in the ER it's open 24hr as any hospital. 12/hr shifts are kind of nice after the first few weeks of adjustment. Yes 3 days, 36hrs but can always pick up a 4ht shift. Working inpatient, Mon-Fri can range from 6am-6pm but in 8hr increments.
cons: As any hospital, no matter how hard of a worker you are you will be dragged into drama. If your good, more responsibilities and then more higher expectations. No pay increase, procedures that don't make sense but you must follow. Gets pretty old. Also, not much room to grow. You may transfer to another dept, say pay grade. Being a team lead for an extra $1 or $2, not worth it as you will be always on call. Don't plan on holidays either or good schedules, only chance of that is if an employee who's been there for years quits (rare) or dies (really rare.) Be prepared for 12hr night shifts if in the ER.

pros: The local management in my location is pretty good. no issues there. The job isn't hard once you've learned how to fix most basic issues.
cons: Not a bad job by any means, it's just extremely stressful, since the management only hires the bare minimum techs to handle an area, so you get very easily overwhelmed when a large number of people put in tickets at once. if you get hired on full time from the contractor position, you only get paid an extra dollar or so per hour.

review_title: If you're looking for work in the Operating Room, choose another facility
job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist II in Austin, TX
pros:
-Friendly staff (once they warm up to you)
-Supply lockers & Scrubs free of charge
-Easy Interview Process
cons:
-What was discussed and offered and accepted throughout the interview/negation process was totally thrown out the door after the (exhaustingly long) orientation period.
-Orientation period or experienced staff lasted 4 months and is as rudimentary as that of a new grad with zero healthcare experience to "keep if fair"
-Call requirements are very confusing and there is more call than I and others in my field have ever experienced
-Scheduled shift can and often does change daily without notice or a cursory "can you....?"
-In less than 1 year there has been 4 different OR Managers

pros: Coworkers on the front lines are hard workers who care about their patients. Teamwork is valued.
cons:
Staff layoffs and stripping labor hours to the bare minimum is a continuous trend. Ascension (and Seton leadership tryiing to please Ascension) keep making cuts to save a few quick dollars despite long term negative consequences such as: higher 30 day re-admission rates, paying out more to third party vendors for staff they cut, low employee morale, lower overall quality of care for patients (not due to morale, due to fewer resources), high RN turnover.
Performance based incentives being cut in 2017. Cost of living increase not given in 2016, performance based increase that should have been given in 2016 was held back until mid 2017. All this amid a top heavy organization with the highest paid CEO in all of non-profit healthcare ($17.6 million annually as of several years ago).

pros: Great people, doctors who care, nurses and support staff are dedicated. Positive interactions with managers and positive attitudes from most of the staff across all clinics. A very special place to work. Precious patients and families who appreciate staff.
cons: Changes in management, work life balance difficult, lack of one on one support from manager to employee. When I needed help the most (mainly when we were short staffed) my manager was often in a meeting, off campus, and unreachable. I felt my needs were not addressed because I would work myself to death for the patients. Too many people complained about being spread too thinly and attitudes of the most positive people suffered.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Austin, TX
pros: Some of the greatest doctors and support staff I have worked with in 20 years!
cons: The administration is awful. They treat the managers bad (high turnover). They make changes without considering the negative impact on patients and staff. They want your voice to be heard but anything said falls on deaf ears. Seton and Ascension health are in financial trouble. Their plans are ridiculous considering all the present problems. Lab is awful (lost our specimen and then got charged to redraw). You will never have PTO for it's intended use because at slow times (6 months) you will be required to use it to cover cancellations.

pros: Good employment benefits and big network of jobs
cons:
Horrible upper management.  Worked to keep prior company open for years and Seton came in and took over.  Seton brought in new management to reorganize and expand.  Physicians did not support employees either after saving their practice.

Unfortunately for me they stated that they needed to get rid of me because of budget cuts (not true)  

Seton has a system of benefiting a group of upper management because they walk in lock step requardless on how they treat employees.  They play favorites and reward certain employees as long as they are good friends of management.

review_title: I enjoyed the work environment and the passion of my supervisors for the work we shared.
pros: Mission/Vision oriented.  Care about doing what is best for the community.  Benefits are solid.  Good at communicating about the vision and how employees can contribute.  Support work/life balance and have a whole section of the organization focused on this.  Offer classes on stress relief and health/wellness.  Prayer and worship is supported.
cons: Big company so slow to change.  Poor performers often get locked into positions and stay for a long time.  Pay seems lower than competitors.  Pay progression is confusing.  New hires can come in a make more or the same as someone who has been with the company for a long time just because of how the company is doing or market trends.  So salary increases seem to lag behind.

review_title: A good company to work for... mostly.
pros: Seton has all the usual benefits with a bit more. Partial tuition reimbursement, decent health insurance, and the usual life/FMLA/STD/stock options. The rural areas are great to work for. Regional clinics and smaller hospitals, especially. The workload and management in these locations are much more pleasant.
cons: If you're clinical or ancillary staff, avoid Brackenridge and certain departments (Med Surg) of Seton Main. You'll be overworked and underpaid with frazzled management in these central / busier locations and dealing with the more "undesireable" elements of society constantly (homeless folks, druggies, alcoholics, prisoners, etc). HR is a mess and takes a long time to accomplish the simplest tasks.

review_title: Great place with great people but clueless/inept leadership.
pros: You will work with some of the most talented, caring, patient-centered individuals in health care.
cons: Since we became more aligned with Ascension, patient care is being treated like a factory assembly line. Clueless leadership push doing more with less (reducing staff, out-sourcing core departments to outside companies who's only focus is the bottom line and not patient care) while complaining about dropping patient satisfaction scores and rising patient complaints. You'd think a fancy business degree would  give them the insight to figure out that unhappy employees = unhappy patients.

pros: The religious and non-profit mission. The potential of what it could be.
cons: The new Humancare advertising campaign is like a psychological reaction-formation to managements inability or unwillingness to do so in practice.  Nothing humancare about this organization.  A very negative and un-supporting environment, which unfortunately, will spill over to patient care.  Unwilling, or unable, to invest in equipment, maintenance, adequate staffing and process improvement to increase productivity and quality.  Instead, just keep piling new things on top of the employees, who can't hardly breathe the way it is.  Then, failures and deficiencies are always the employees fault, not the system.  Instead of real efforts, continuous campaign slogans and new computer modules to fill out.  Be wary of the turn-over at this organization, it is saying something.

pros: You work only 3 days a week. You get to submit your own schedule. Most of the nurses and doctors, etc were great to work with. You get a few discounts such as gym memberships and cell phone contract discounts. You get to live in Austin, which is a really cool city except for the traffic and high rent for apartments.
cons: Austin under pays nurses big time! You can make much twice as much in Houston or Dallas.  I would of tolerated working here if they paid me more.  The CEO has over a million dollar salary but cuts jobs and adds more responsibility on to the nurses. Medsurg nursing can burn you out no matter which hospital you work at. Nursing is more about charting than actual patient care.  We need to put more emphasis on preventing chronic diseases instead of managing them.

job_title: Applications Systems Analyst  in Austin, TX
pros: Great compensation and benefits.  It's a large network with lots of opportunities for growth.  As a non-profit, most if not all employees seemed truly concerned about their patients & giving back to the community.
cons: The religious affliation was a downside to me.  It does seem to permeate the atmosphere.  It is a large & complex organization so depending on who you work for & in what department you can either thrive or stagnate.  I started working in a department that was really fragmented and had so many internal problems that I was not appropriately trained to do my job.  I felt like I was just treading water for the 2 years I worked there.  It was very frustrating and eventually lended to my leaving.

review_title: Starting salary criminally low for cost of living in Austin
pros: Provides care for all people even if uninsured
No real oversight - you can literally do whatever you want
cons: They took away all incentive to do you job well.  You will not be rewarded for working twice as hard as your coworkers.   They put the least experienced people into leadership roles and they don't know what they're doing.  Hard work, above and beyond are overlooked.  There is literally NO opportunity for advancement unless you're the "golden child" of the moment.  Opportunities are given to who they want without fair notice or fair shot, by the time they post a position they've already decided who will get it so don't bother to apply.  Nothing is ever communicated except by word of mouth.  Misinformation is rampant.   Things that directly affect me are never officially discussed, just rumored.

review_title: Not for profit is a joke CEO makes upwards of 1.8 million
pros: At least it's a job
cons: Salaries not that great unless you are a director or one of the 10,000 VPs they keep hiring.  Upper level mgmt keeps increasing in numbers  while pay and benefits for front line employees keep getting worse,  poor PTO and holiday benefits,  retirement benefits just got changed for the worse,  budget cuts are usually directed at staffing leaving very over worked/stressed employees,  not much reward for the kind of stressful work you have to do,  administration has no real regard for the employees

pros:
Generally supportive co-workers, peers and managers.
Excellent training program for new-grad nurses in the form of the Versant program
Competitive benefits
Constantly tries to give back to, support and participate in local communities (Austin and surrounding areas).
Seems to generally genuinely believe in doing ethical work in the way that it treats its employees, patients and communities.
cons:
Some of the facilities are older and not as attractive or user friendly (for employees, patients and visitors) as the competing (for-profit) hospital network.
Because it is a Catholic hospital network, not all reproductive options are available or even allowed to be discussed (for example, birth control can not be discussed with women, emergency contraception is not discussed or offered to ER/rape victims, and sterilization procedures such as tubal ligations can not be performed in any Seton facility).

pros:
Affordable Health Insurance
Great working environment/ work-life balance
Tuition Reimbursement
Community focused
Opportunities for advancement due to the size of the company
Flexible work schedules
cons:
-Pay is below national standards for most positions.  One could easily leave the company and get a $10k increase simply by going to work for another company

- Slow to move and acquire new technology

- quality of patient care needs significant improvement

 - very top heavy organization where Directors,  Senior Directors and VP's abound

- Easily spends significant amounts of money on consultants that tend to keep getting new(continuous) contracts yet will not offer competitive salaries for their own employees.  

- Significant layoffs occur every 2 years which can make for an unstable/non-long-term workplace

pros: You won't be over-worked and getting time off is never a problem.  Deadlines are pretty much optional and working arrangements are pretty flexible.
cons: There is no accountability and no merit promotions.  So, every year, if HR decides a "market adjustment" is needed for a particular job code, everyone in that job code receives the same percent increase in pay (which usually only amounts to two to three percent anyway).  The culture is very centered around "tribal knowledge" which gives certain long standing members of departments much more job security than they should have.  A common management tactic for addressing problems is "ignore it and see if it goes away".

pros: Excellent benefits, large network with an abundance of opportunity for all positions.  Higher education encouraged, very high standards and expectations of performance criteria.  Magnet facility with respectable reputation in area.
cons: Treatment of employees from department to department not consistent.  In some cases, favortism is exhibited.  Would reccommend anyone applying be given a tour an opportunity to meet curent employees, ask questions, and get a feel for if it's an appropriate fit.

pros: Location-Central Texas; working in a now 3 hospital system which should give them a heavy advantage on market share and rates
cons: Seton has no strategy or plan on how to be successful.  Their leadership is reactive based on the monthly financials and their quality is poor in their hospitals due to the deep cuts to the 25th percentile of nursing.  Meanwhile, their executive team keeps increasing their pay and losing market share.  Heavily reliant on Dell Children's hospital as their only primary revenue source.

review_title: Low morale, extremely overworked and blatant lack of respect for employees
pros: The co-workers I have are amazing. This is the only reason I still work for Seton.
cons:
After almost 4yrs at Seton, it has become blatantly clear that staffing/pay issues are ignored. We've been kept at a skeleton crew for almost a year and half. NOT OKAY SETON!! The few of us that remain are beyond overworked. Management is horrible. Do not work here. 

The opportunity for career advancement is non-existent. There is no career ladder whatsoever.

review_title: Tremendous Opportunities to Help Improve Lives of Central Texans
pros: You are working with other people who are engaged in the cause of raising the health standard and well-being of Central Texans. Everyone is treated with respect. The pay is fair to good and the benefits are outstanding. There is a premium placed on people who are problem solvers.
cons: There are a small percentage of people who see any change as negative and resist. They probably started in healthcare when it was more static, before the advent of data-driven decision making. They can really wipe out your good mood.

review_title: Used to Be A Great Place...
pros:
Varying schedules
Good pay
Employee discounts to COTA
Good job for medical students if they can't get a CA job
Tuition reimbursement
cons:
No incentives other than salary 
Lots of outsourcing since becoming a part of AHN
Loyalty not well rewarded
Constant threat of downsizing in any department
Minimal to no budget which means lack of tools to perform job
High turnover rate

pros:
good supervision
collaborative atmosphere
great place for learning on the job
tons of services for people
good insurance
Local management is great!
cons:
Ascension's (company that owns Seton) communication with staff is pretty poor and vague goals that aren't specific to a department.  Not a ton of local control regarding clinic decision making, becoming more bureaucratic.

Having to call Minnesota for HR needs

Tech support is not good - if you're non essential equipment breaks and doesn't impact patient care you're going to wait for a while before anything gets done and tech support we do get frequently does not resolve the issue (computers, phones, faxes, internet access, email, HR information, time-card issues, etc...)

pros: Easy interview process (was hired after a Skype interview from out of state). My nursing manager worked with me beautifully when I had to take time off for being admitted to the hospital. Benefits kicked in the first of the month following your start date, regardless of what day you started.
cons: Pay, bad overall attitude (coworkers, charge nurses), no growth opportunity (was promised CA3 after training telemetry but was not actually promoted). Rushed through training and thrown out on your own if you have experience elsewhere.

job_title: Senior Department Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Seton has really great benefits.  They do practice what they preach of healing the whole self and passing that down to employees through spiritual employee lunches, tranquility gardens, chair massages during lunch, etc.
cons: Large company - career track is not always easy to manuever.  Seems like there is a constant cycle of lifting a hiring freeze, reintroducing another hiring freeze, and then a large layoff.

review_title: Wonderful Co-Workers!  The management is terrible however and what I mean is the Ascension super power.
pros: Those employees who have stayed thru the Ascension transition, are actually there because they want to be.  Even though they are not valued, they want to care for the patients.
cons: Ascension has ruined Seton Family.  Simply ruined it.  They were a care-centric and employee-centric business before Ascensions Take Over.  Now?  They are disorganized, non-caring to employees who have tenure, turn a blind eye to every complaint and put out fires instead of preventative processes.

job_title: Material Operations Manager in Austin, TX
pros: The salary was very competitive.  The people I worked with were a great group overall.  It was a fun atmosphere most of the time.
cons: It was very disorganized.  We had a new project every other month which seemed to be 180 degrees different than the last project we were given.  The director also played favorites.  If she liked you, you were golden.  If not, watch out.  She would bad mouth you to others in the organization.

pros:
Decent benefits and pay
Several new facilities
Some coworkers who really care
Decent retirement package
Multiple locations 
New state of the art equipment at some locations
cons:
Hires or promotes incompetent people and then leaves them in place to fail repeatedly
Admin/management listens to concerns and/or problems but does little to address them unless there is a financial motivation
Clinical ladders which force employees to spend more time trying to hold on to their current pay grade than performing their job
Complete lack of transparency 
More concerned with image and public perception than providing the best care for patients

review_title: Charge Nurse Emergency Department Dell Seton Medical Center
pros: Great staff, the best in the city in terms of the people you get to work with. We have the best doctors for an ED too. Our managers really care. Several nurses, RTs, and other clinical staff have been there forever. which makes it really feel like a family. There is a top-notch nurse residency for new nurses. There is also a very good transition fellowship if you are interested in transitioning to a new specialty.
cons: The company was taking over by Ascension Health. Ascension is making things more corporate and this has an effect on morale. There is not much room to move up. We have had layoffs at least 3 times in the 10 years I have worked for the Seton network. I wanted to apply for an Infection Preventionist position but about a month before I could apply, the head of Infection Prevention was laid off because they eliminated her position. This made me scared to apply. I had friends try and apply for supervisor positions only to find out that the positions they were applying for were eliminated before they could even interview. They also eliminated jobs for Spanish interpreters, Social Workers, and Child Life specialists who are still greatly needed. These job eliminations put a lot more stress on nurses who have to do more and more with less and less.

pros: At the unit level this is an awesome place to work. Incredible team work, very caring staff that enjoys working with our under-insured/unfunded patient  population. Recent pay increases have gotten nurses closer to a sustainable pay level in a very expensive city. Staff believe in the mission even if national level leadership simply use it as talking points with no follow thru. Unit level managers are very good and supportive of staff. Moving soon to a brand new facitity.
cons: Zero transparency in national leadership, unit level managers often find out about changes that effect staff negatively the same day as staff. Hospital CEO, regional and national leaders have no idea what it takes to run a Level 1/ safety net facility. They seem to think beating on the front line staff about satisfaction  survey scores and cost cutting will somehow improve care but they seem to forget that outcomes are the true measurement of a hospitals patient care. Ascension doesn't know how to run a REAL teaching hospital, so instead they try to run UMCB like their other community hospitals. If your not a YES person that thinks every thing that comes out of leaderships mouth is the best idea ever they will try to get rid of you .HumanCare is a joke, $$$ Care is the new reality for national leadership. Promotions are based on you nodding and smiling about every flawed idea that directors and above make.

review_title: State of the Art OR With Supportive Management
job_title: Operating Room RN in Round Rock, TX
pros: Management is very supportive, benefits are competitive with other hospitals and parking is free. They have an excellent state of the art OR with the latest technology including the most advanced robotic and video assisted devices. The OR staff and physicians provide a full range surgical procedures.  I have been an OR nurse for more than 10 years and this OR is one of the best ORs I have ever worked in.
cons: It is difficult for a PRN RN employed by a single Ascension Seton facility to work concurrently in other Seton facilities.

review_title: Not bad, not what it used to be either.
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Austin, TX
pros: Patient Ratios were always reasonable and patient safety was a focus.
cons:
After Ascension took over, the managers they hired were less nurse-centric, more worried about pleasing upper management at whatever the cost. The old, great managers ended up quitting or were let go. The old Seton functioned great.  New Seton still gives good care but at the cost of the nurses. 

Also, Seton only hires new nurses. Rarely do they hire experienced nurses. Its the inexperienced teaching the brand new. Not safe.

review_title: Looking for a good job... keep looking... this is not it!!!
pros: its employment... that is the only thing that is positive about this employer. Beats being unemployed
cons: management plays more games than the employees, unprofessional environment, employees do what they want if you friends with supervisors. The training is rhetoric and never get implemented. Last minute and inconsistent decisions made that usually result in a disaster

review_title: Many Organizational Incongruousnesses: Mission and Values vs. Policy and Culture
pros:
Competitive Pay
Teaching Hospital
Progressive Employee Ladder Program
Shared Governance and Committees 
Okay Staffing Ratios
cons:
Outdated Charting System
Draconian Rules
Keep your head down, do your job, make everyone happy
"Good 'Ol Boys/Girls Club"
Inconsistent Policies and Training 
Okay Staffing Ratios

pros: Great people work here lots of training and refresh courses every year. Safety is important here and following procedures. Everyone is invited to question things you feel are not correct it's okay.
cons: Huge turnaround in IT/ Support Services because competition in other industry with better pay you see people with great knowledge leave for better paying jobs.

review_title: Good people but enough cons to leave
pros: Good people, pay was median for market, mission was a focus, a growing focus on development, but
cons: Would have been nice if the focus on development would have started earlier and not expected to occur at pace it did.  For a while, there was a new accountability or goal report added to a managers responsibility without addition of support.  Systems were frustrating at times. Hiring process was extremely slow and bureaucratic, even for entry level back fills.

review_title: CEO of Ascension made $8.5 million in 2013
pros: None.  Turnover is very high so they are always hiring.
cons: Nurses and underpaid (much less than Houston/Dallas) and understaffed.  Techs and underpaid and understaffed.  I worked in the pharmacy and my starting in 2014 was the exact same as the starting pay in 2010.  Company brought in highly paid consultants to see if they could cut even more staff in the pharmacy, but didn't find any staffing cuts b/c we were already at minimal staffing.  They did the same exact thing they did a few years and made staffing cuts.

pros: Fun environment.  Lot's of training, promotional opportunities.  Career paths are highly defined and their rewards and recognition programs are top notch.  I highly recommend this company to anyone who is seeking career advancement with an industry leading organization.
cons: There are few cons.  If I had to single out a few it would be in the area of competition.  There are so many talented people employed by this company, it is easy to get lost in the mix.  You have to bring your A-Game to the table.

review_title: Non-profit in name and advertising only
pros: Generally get to work with some good people.  Benefits and compensation that really benefits anyone who is starting their careers, or for someone who spent their whole, and is in the tail-end, of their career.
cons:
This is basically a corporate company, in the way it's run, and mentality.  Technically, you could call it a non-profit, as any profit would go to the exorbitant salary and bonuses - so I guess, after you pay that out, there is no profit.  They like to tout that each hospital is a ministry, and that the reason the pay is so low, is that you get the intrinsic benefit of helping those less fortunate.  If that's the case, then why is it for a "non-profit" hospital, executive management, make above and beyond the compensation package of FOR -profit companies?  Don't they feel the "intrinsic benefit", of working for less pay?

 I can only speak of my experience in what was used to be the IT department.  As Seton is part of Ascension Health, and as they push for more standardization, Seton is the only one that outsources their IT to Dell (maybe in no small part to the HUGE contribution to the Dell Children's Medical Center, or the fact that the top guy in Seton IT, used to be an Account Manager for Dell)... Hmmm.

There are also incredible inefficiencies in decision making, as usually it'll take months, and go through 6 different project managers, for a "project" just to make a decision, on doing a project.  They'll tell you, that you need a project number to have a project, but then when you actually have a project, and ask for information, and give them the project number, they'll say, they can't look up project numbers... LOL 

HIPAA... Let's just say, you really need to improve.

pros: Good benefits, tuition reimbursement, regular training and drills, annual nurses banquet, flexible schedule and opportunities for transfers and advancement. I love my coworkers!
cons: At seton northwest, the management on the medical surgical floor can be petty. They are very nice and aim to improve patient satisfaction scores, understandable, but expectations can be in realistic. Over the past two years, ascension took over and bonus amounts have dropped and we all received no pay raise this year! That's right, not one cent. Kind of a slap in the face for all our loyalty and hard work.

job_title: Senior LVN II in Moss Beach, CA
pros: The company is great to work for. However, the location itself needs a lot of improvement.
cons:
The facility has less than stellar conditions; a lot of smells which are easily preventable, and very shoddy-looking condition.  I would not feel comfortable moving a family member there.
I was originally hired at a rate of $40.20, which was not unfamiliar to me in my previous job. A couple weeks after I completed new employee orientation and started working full-time shifts, I received a call from HR that they screwed up on my base pay and that they were cutting my pay by almost half! I asked to meet somewhere in the middle as I would not have taken the job at almost half my original offer and they said no. I needed the job and I needed a job close to home so I stayed. Over the year I worked there I offered ONCE to work an overnight shift and told the scheduler that I cannot work night shift all the time. I did that once before and I got very ill because I never adjusted my sleep schedule properly. I was the only one that would do it, they were desperate for someone to take over and ended up scheduling me every overnight shift. After 2 months I lost my position because they hired 3 new day shift employees and one of them took my spot. That was very unprofessional. I communicated this to upper management and the response was that they needed to fill the schedule how "Nancy (the scheduler) wants the schedule filled". I have never seen such unprofessional behavior in over 20 years of work. The only way I would go back to that establishment is if all upper management and the scheduler were replaced by new people.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Austin, TX
pros: I really like the documentation computer system (Compass), it is user friendly and organized.  The pay is competitive to what is available in the area.  The company treats their employees well.  Due to working in the float pool I was able to set my days to work.
cons: I worked in the float pool and ended up being a sitter more often than working as a PCT on a unit.  There were also times that work would not be available when calling in to receive my assignment and would not work that day.

job_title: Clinical Assistant Ll in Burnet, TX

Management even told me one time it was my fault that I got treated the way I do when all I did was show up early and work my backside off. Also management showed favortism towards seasoned employees and never eanted to hear both sides.

review_title: Seton Family of Hospitals is a stable, growing company.  For the most part it is a really good experience for employees.

review_title: The employees were treated like we were expendable

job_title: RN Case Manager in Austin, TX

review_title: Seton is a wonderful employer to work for.

review_title: Poor ability to apply its Missions and Work ethics to employees within their employment

pros: Decent pay, good benefits, nice working environment, great co-workers.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist II in Austin, TX
pros: The pay is competitive, the benefits are decent, there is a large scope of responsibilities, most co workers are pleasant to work with.
cons: Too much forced overtime, management is not concerned with employee well-being, management is more focused on profit and volume rather than patient care, vacation and time off is often denied, management not available in work related crisis situations (traumas, equipment malfunctions, system outages), management shows no admiration for hard working employees.

review_title: Wonderful transition from graduate nurse to professional nurse
pros: Wonderful staff with team and family centered nursing care. Great child life program with many resources and activities for patients. Clean, eco-friendly facilities
cons: A lot of turnover in upper management in the past year.  Occasionally micro-managing with new policies that have been rolled out since.

pros: The work environment and team are fantastic.  Work load is usually just right.  Pretty good benefits.
cons: Pay is less than I was making as a new grad in another Texas city.  No room for advancement in my area.  Being a Catholic based organization spills over into healthcare options.

review_title: Brackenridge Hospital: "Mission" is only based on profit (quite sad!)
pros: For Breckenridge Hospital:  It's hard to think many Pro's. The hospital has a false sense of security - don't get too comfortable in your role. The people appear to be somewhat friendly to your face - be careful how open & friendly you get though. Being in the new Dell Medical school building is the only thing to look forward to this company has faced in half a century.
cons:
For Breckenridge Hospital:
- Salary & benefits are no where near competitive for the Austin market. People complain of this all the time on their "Setonville" internal news portal all the time about this. There has been very little rise in wages & no added benefits even though the Austin has grown tremendously in cost of living.
- The company tries to make everything about the "mission"/"values," but in the end, things are all about the bottom line ($) & productivity numbers. As someone who worked in & with administration, trust me, i know.. BEWARE!
- Why are people that are non-clinical/non-patient interacting (i.e. administration) required to dress up every single day? Ever heard of casual Fridays?
- The staff will make you seem that your work is in very "team" based environment, but don't let this get to your head, since if you fall behind on anything.. everything will go ON YOU alone! Nobody to help pick up the pieces.
- Most people have been put in positions and have been stuck there for years without any sort of advancement opportunities.
- Everything is dictated by the parent company, Ascension. The hospital itself has no backbone.
- A lot of employees are overworked and there is NO WORK-LIFE BALANCE. It doesn't matter what position you have, you'll get VERY little PTO (which is combined with sick leave, so if you ever fall ill, you'll have no time off for other things!). Even if you do end up building up PTO, it's nearly impossible to take it and almost looked frowned upon (this won't be expressed to you, but talked behind your back guaranteed).

pros: Clean environment, given necessary tools/resources to perform job well, friendly staff, location, benefits
cons: High turnover rate(this seems to be a lab trend vs hospital-specific), schedule, PTO accrual rate, staffing

review_title: Seton has been a great place to develop as an individual.
pros: The therapy department is super supportive, and they are a fun group of people to work with. I have really enjoyed my 5 years here.
cons: Working one weekend/month and covering holidays is not the best scenario, but you get used to it and plan around it etc. There is not a whole lot of opportunity to climb the professional ladder.

review_title: Used to be a good company, now ok

pros: Benefits are pretty decent. Sense of community is strong

pros: Cost of benefits, great co-workers, nice city with lots todo.  Multiple hospitals close together.  Multiple specialties to find your passion.  Teaching facilities.

review_title: Large organization that is easy going.
